Situation1: They are asked to take part in an important family event like a holiday celebration or trip.
Expectation2: Follow all instructions provided by election officials
Situation2: A poll worker requests that the voter re-sign a smudged envelope so the ballot will not risk rejection later.
Story: I stood in the hallway, my phone buzzing with messages from my sister. “Don’t be late! Mom’s counting on you to help with the decorations.” Today was our family’s big holiday celebration, and everyone expected me to be there, laughing and sharing stories, just like every year. But I was also at the polling station, ballot in hand, ready to vote for the first time. The poll worker frowned at my envelope. “I’m sorry, but the signature smudged. Please re-sign here, exactly as before, or your vote might not count.” I glanced at the clock, feeling the weight of both worlds pressing down. My family needed me, but so did my civic duty. The poll worker’s eyes were patient but firm, while my phone kept buzzing with reminders of my brotherly role. My heart pounded as I stood between the two, torn by the fear of disappointing my family or failing to follow the voting instructions. I hesitated, caught in the middle, unsure which expectation to meet first.
